												Favorite FPS overall. I still prefer it to Red Orchestra 2. I wouldn’t say it’s popular, but it isn’t completely dead either: there’s at least one active European server that gets full every day. There’s one in the U.S. too. Even the development process isn’t entirely dead. Modders from  The Darkest Hour  team have released a number of major updates in 2016 and will continue the development in 2017.


YouTube™ Video: Red Orchestra is a helluva game. 

			Views: 1,366		

			Multiplayer Gameplay from Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 and the mod for it, Darkest Hour. I used Fraps. Acer Aspire 5733Z Windows 7 Home Premium 64-bit Intel(R) Pentium(R) CPU P6100 @ 2.00GHz (2...		

(video by Joe Smhoe)Pros (compared to RO2)Slower pacing. People don’t tend to run around at breakneck speeds quite as much. Twitch reactions are not as important, and this game is noticeably easier to play for me. Weapon balance. Weapons have a lot more recoil and sway when shooting from standing or crouching position. This means that resting your weapon on random objects for support is very important and players tend to use cover more. Simple bolt-action rifles are incredibly powerful: they do a lot of damage and are significantly more accurate than semi-autos. You can either have good rate of fire or good accuracy (RO2 semi-autos, by contrast, give you both, and an SVT-40 is almost always better than a Mosin). One could argue that this isn’t very realistic, but it makes playing as a rifleman fun, whereas in HoS it can be very hard and frustrating. Or maybe I’m just hopelessly bad at playing rifleman in RO2.No spawning on squad leaders. You have to actually walk or ride from spawn to the capzone. It increases the value of your life and value of life of your enemies. When you kill someone, he’s not going to respawn in vaguely the same place in 10 seconds. You won’t see him again in at least half a minute (or more for large maps). And it helps to avoid the situation where if you spawn on SL, you're likely to immediately die, but if you don’t, you’re not in the capzone, you’re not helping your team cap, you’re not protecting your SL. Survival in situations like these depends largely on luck: if you happen to spawn behind cover, you’re good, but if you spawn in the open where one of the enemy machine gunners can see you, you’re boned and will have to try again. This can be very annoying in RO2. Darkest Hour (a mod) has one of the best spawning mechanics I’ve seen in this type of game: MDVs (Mobile Deploy Vehicles). Basically, an MDV is an APC with a spawn point inside. You can park it anywhere, but it’s bulky and noisy — hiding it behind enemy lines can be tricky. When you spawn in it, you can have a look around and hop out when you think it’s safe-ish. Or, if it clearly isn’t, you can try moving it to a better position. It’s vulnerable to satchels, panzershrecks and whatnot, so the chance to die immediately after spawning is still there, but at least it’s not random and it’s very rare.No stat grinding or unlocks. When you start playing, your weapon is identical to the ones used by players who have played this game for years. They won’t have faster running speed, faster reloads or resistance to suppression. Joining a winning team won’t make you level up faster, and blatant team stacking is fairly rare. Most matches feel more balanced.No UAVs. You can use vegetation and ruined buildings to hide for a long time and nobody’s going to find you unless they see or hear you. Unfortunately, people can still fly around as spectators when they’re waiting in a spawn queue. There’s a mutator that blacks out the screen when the player is dead, but most servers don’t run it nowadays.Plenty of large combined arms maps with open design, including some really huge tank-centric maps. There’s an achievement for destroying a tank at 2000+ meters. And popular servers actually run these: it’s not like Counter-Strike or TF2, where there are thousands of community maps available, but most servers stick to stocks like de_dust2 and cp_dustbowl.Huge variety of weapons and vehicles. You can play as Soviets, Germans, Americans, Brits, Australians, Canadians, Romanians, Italians, Hungarians, Poles and Finns. Some of the vehicles included: BA-64 (aka the clown car), Panzer II Flamm and OT-34 (flamethrower tanks!), ISU-152 (152 mm self-propelled gun), Sturmtiger, Sturer Emil, Marder III Ausf. M, SdKfz 234/2 “Puma”, BMW R71 motorcycle (with or without sidecar), ZiS-3 truck, Willys and Volkswagen Kübelwagen, STZ-5 (although it’s used as an infantry transport) and even a farming tractor. Not to mention a good number of Italian and Hungarian tanks (even World of Tanks doesn’t have these). There are AT and FlaK guns, boats, planes you can paradrop from, mortars you carry around and setup wherever you like. You can also use tanks to transport infantry.Tank crewmen can get out of their vehicles and get back in. It adds immersion, allows you to park your tank in a safe place, get out and gather intel with your binoculars (silhouette of a person with binocs is nowhere near as noticeable as a tank on the horizon). It also makes it possible to bail out and continue fighting on foot or join a different crew when your tank is damaged. Tank crew frantically getting out of a burning tank is something you’ll never see in RO2. Team-tanking is fun and useful, whereas in HoS you’re often better off with bots even if you use voip. It’s just faster to press W and have your tank move forward immediately. In RO:Ost, it is faster to switch to driver and press W too, but you won’t be able to reload the gun at the same time. Or keep an eye on the enemy. So, a fully crewed tank with voice comms is likely to outmaneuver a solo tanker, which isn’t true in RO2.I love the way you have to turn the tank turrets using keyboard, not mouse. Having to control each axis separately is more immersive than just pointing at the target with a mouse cursor. It feels more like turning two separate cranks.Your character won’t give away your position by making random loud remarks while you’re trying to sneak.There are doors you can open and close. Even Wolfenstein 3D had this feature, but RO2 doesn’t. Cons (compared to RO2)Low population.Automatic weapons arguably have too much recoil and are hard to use.Weaker physics. Bullets and shells don’t penetrate objects. Vehicles can occasionally get stuck on flimsy obstacles like picket fences. Nonadjustable sniper rifle scopes.No squads, no fireteams, no tactical view. You can’t mark enemies on the map.Many of the really cool features are only available in  DH, and most popular servers for this mod are in the U.S. (high pings for players from Asia).Tank interiors are not as detailed, there’s no animation for individual crewmen.No way to kick people out of your tank if you don’t trust them.No Japanese, no maps set in the Pacific, no jungle. No flamethrowers for infantry, swords, booby traps.Every character on your team has the same voice, and the number of lines they can say is very limited.P.S. I’m not saying Red Orchestra 2 is a bad game, it’s definitely worth getting too.

												Part 1.Super game. The most realistic game of all time, there are shoals of small, but otherwise the game супер.Very much types of guns, tanks etc.The predecessor of Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 is a modification of Red Orchestra: the Combined Arms for Unreal Tournament 2004, created by enthusiasts, who later organized the company Tripwire Interactive.Modification participated in the contest «Make Something Unreal», conducted by Epic Games, creators of the games «Unreal». Due to the subsequent victory, the command Tripwire Interactive received the prize pool and a license for commercial use of the game engine, Unreal Engine 2.5. Later it was decided to move the modification of the format of individual games, elaborating some elements.The game takes place on the Eastern front during the Second world war and covers the period from 1941 to 1945. The player is given the opportunity to participate in the reconstruction of events as for the Red Army and Wehrmacht troops. The game is targeted primarily at the network mode, but there's a single-player game against the bots. Each location (map) is a real historical area.In multiplayer mode, the player can take any direction - both Soviet and German soldiers. In addition, there are several types of slot classes with their own unique capabilities and skills for the use of certain weapons. There is a possibility to manage a real military equipment, such as tanks, mobile artillery, artillery guns, armoured troop carriers.For Red Orchestra was done many custom modifications, such as the sets of cards, a variety of game content or full total conversion.Below is a list of published or under development projects:Carpathian Crosses - focuses on the participation of Romania in the Second world war. No longer supported by developers.Mare Nostrum - focuses on the Mediterranean theater of operations.Darkest Hour: Normandy 1944 - focuses on the capture of Normandy.After-Hourz Community - includes several new vehicles, new tanks and anti-tank weapons.Defence Alliance 2 - ported by the authors of UT2004.Part 2.Red Orchestra concentrates mostly on the multiplayer aspect of the game, although there is a singleplayer "Practice" mode available. Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 features an advanced ballistics system for both small arms and tank rounds - incorporating bullet drop, flight time, and tanks with more realistic armor properties than most games (featuring: penetration and deflection, in relation to range and projectile trajectory angle). The player's movements are realistically modeled, giving them the ability to lie and move prone, sprint (while standing or crouching) and to deploy machine guns on objects.Red Orchestra is notable for its emphasis on realism in comparison to other World War II-based FPS games. There is no "crosshair" for a player to aim with in the middle of their screen; instead, the player must either aim down the three-dimensional iron sights, or aim from the hip using the game's free-aim system. The former requires compensating for the breathing of the character and natural sway from holding the gun, while the latter is much quicker but accurate only at very short range. The player must also keep track of their ammo usage mentally unlike many other FPS games, most of which use an ammunition counter. Additionally, the player's health status is not represented by "health points" as many other games use, but by a diagram of the player's body with reddened sections that show where he or she has been wounded; there is no way to recover from wounds, although after a brief period of time, the player will function at 100% again. Receiving wounds will temporarily slow the player down, especially if they receive a wound to the legs or feet; receiving a wound to the hands causes the player to drop their currently held weapon on the ground. Rifles usually kill players in one shot if they connect with the torso or head.Vehicle support is also a prominent feature of the game. The player can operate the combat vehicles as one of the crew members. Most tanks, for example, can accommodate up to three crew members (a driver, a commander and a machine-gunner) to make them fully effective in close city fighting, however it is easy to crew a tank solo and simply switch to different positions as needed. When grouped together in a vehicle, all players in the vehicle receive points for their actions and for the actions of their fellow crew members; for example, if a player is driving a tank and the tank commander destroys an enemy tank, both the player and the commander will receive the appropriate number of points for that kill. When operating a tank solo, the player can only perform one of the roles at a time; this prevents a solo player from being able to fire, move and reload all at the same time (reloading is a task performed by the commander). The game also features artillery support in some maps which can be utilized by both squad leaders and tank commanders.The game received generally favorable reviews from critics. On the review aggregator Game Rankings, the game had an average score of 81% based on 22 reviews. On Metacritic, the game had an average score of 81 out of 100, based on 22 reviews

												What sets this apart from other multiplayer co-op first person shooters? A strong emphasis on realism and historical accuracy. The closest comparison to this game might be Enemy Territory: Quake Wars, but Team Fortress and Counterstrike are in the same genre. Basically you've got two teams and you've got to attack/defend various objectives within a time limit. But those other games are far more forgiving; if you get shot you can just use a medkit, if you get a baddie in your crosshairs just pull the trigger.Well, in Red Orchestra there are no crosshairs for most guns, and there is no health regeneration. If you get shot even once you're probably dead. Expect to die a lot in this game. Fortunately the respawn times are short!Other realistic aspects include significant recoil and reload times for most guns. In Team Fortress you'll be spraying bullets everywhere without worrying about aiming or ammo. In Red Orchestra you've got to make every bullet count, because there's no auto-aim and ammo is limited. Even if you end up with a machine gun you'll get much better results firing short controlled bursts rather than spraying bullets everywhere. Realists rejoice!There's a large number of maps to choose from, all of which are based on or at least inspired by real World War 2 battles between the Germans and Soviets. A great amount of work went into making sure the uniforms and equipment were historically accurate, and even that the interiors of the tanks looked realistic.TANKS! Yes, there's more tanks than you can shake a stick at in this game. Tanks are very hard to destroy and can easily mow down waves of attacking infantry, but they are not invincible. On many maps the gameplay will involve trying to destroy the other team's tanks, or getting your own tanks to the objective. Tank armor is strongest in front, weaker on the sides, and weakest in the rear. So a lot of tank battles involve trying to sneak up on enemy tanks from the sides or rear. It helps that tank crews have a restricted field of view, so it's easier than you might think to ambush them!There are some other vehicles too but they are mostly transports with a secondary anti-infantry role. The realism may put off some players. As a WW2 history buff I know that a Tiger tank is much better than a Panzer III tank, but a casual gamer offered the choice of getting into one tank or another couldn't be expected to know that. The fact that there are so many tanks and they mostly look alike compounds the problem, although it is realistic. Did I mention this game is complicated? There's a key to fix a bayonet to your rifle, a key to change the barrel of your machine gun if it overheats, a key to pop open the hatch of your tank to get a better field of view...need I go on? Expect a steep learning curve.My main complaint is that teams can become unbalanced rather easily. A game with 8 players vs 6 will see the smaller team struggling to survive. I guess I got spoiled by the auto team-balancing mechanic of ET:QW and TF; I just always assumed a game in this genre would have it. On some servers bots can be substituted for people to balance teams, but bots are a bit of a wild card. They can be awesome marksmen as infantry, but they're hopeless when driving any kind of vehicle.There is no single player component. The soundtrack is appropriate and non-intrusive. I got this game practically for free in a sale; buy it if it's $5 or less.If you're a World War 2 history buff or you liked Enemy Territory: Quake Wars then you'll like Red Orchestra.

												Red Orchestra is notable for its emphasis on realism in comparison to other World War II-based FPS games. 												Red Orchestra: Ostfront is one of the hidden gems of the FPS world. I'm not sure why Steam says I only played 65 hours. It was much more than that.Combining realistic tank and infantry combat into a seamless experience (though some maps are tank- or infantry-only), this game delivers a realistic WW2 immersion that the CoD and BF series only dream of. Major pros:-Realistic weaponry, human and tank damage models-Team-based tactics; no lone-wolf BS-Historical maps-You can hip-shoot a freaking MG-42 (but unless you're Audie Murphy, I wouldn't advise it)-Tank projectile physics are fairly realistic (e.g., shells deflect at high incidence angles)-Lots of types of tanks to drive-You can call artillery support (and not just for getting a certain amount of kills), though the mark has to be in a good spot to be effective!Cons:-Probably the only major con is the lack of a single player campaign. The AI is so terrible, that laying the maps in single-player is really boring and pointless. However, this game from the start was always meant to be multiplayer. And in that regard, it delivers in spades. -Certainly not a deal-breaker, but compared to CoD2, which came out around a similar time, the character and vehicle animations are rather robotic and artificial-No Tiger IIB-Really nothing else

												A really good WW2 sim, with realistic bullet physics like drop and breathing, with you being able to mount or brace a weapon against walls , or mount machineguns or anti-Tank rifles. There is a large selection of maps by default, with great mod support with new theatres other than the Eastern Front, like Crete and North Africa in Mare Nostrum or Normandy, the Ardennes and France in Darkest Hour. The graphics are dated and the standard Multiplayer is dead as disco. However the game has bots and LAN games, just dont expect 64 people per server. There is a large selection of weapons depending on the date of the map you are playing on, ranging from bolt action rifles like the Kar-98 and Mosin Nagant, to rare protype weapons such as the G41 semi-automatic rifle (Replaced by the G43 in later maps.) The tanks have multiple round types, and sloped front or turret armor can cause tank rounds to ricochet, so plenty of practice is needed to command a tank and its crew. Many tank/transport models appear in the game like the German Panzer IV, Tiger, SDKFZ 250/1 Half track, as well as Soviet tanks like the KV1 and T34/75.

												NOTE:*****At the time of this review, this game is dead or dying in terms of its playerbase, buy at your own risk.*****June 22, 1941. Breaking his nonaggression pact with Josef Stalin, Adolf Hitler launches Operation Barbarossa, the invasion of the Soviet Union and begins one of the longest and most brutal campaigns in modern military history. Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 masterfully captures this front of the second world war like no other game to date. Red Orchestra is a realistic, team based, multiplayer first person shooter. It is not a simulator like the ARMA series, but is still a game that must played with the upmost seriousness. The game places you into the boots of a soldier in the Soviet Red Army or in the German Ostheer and allows you to assume the different roles of infantry or armored vehicle crewmen. Players can assume a variety of roles from riflemen, assault troopers, and tank crewman to snipers, sappers, tank hunters and tank commanders. Some roles are leadership roles, with the purpose of guiding and ordering your teammates to victory like squad leaders and tank commanders, with the ability to call in support, like devastating artillery strikes. Combat is realistic, tough, and gruesome. Every mistake is punished by death. Infantry must work together, take cover, and use real world tactics, with different roles coordinating with each other to achieve victory. Vehicle crews must also communicate and coordinate if they are to survive, let alone win, whether it's in an APC transporting troops to the frontlines or engaging enemy tanks as a gunner in your own tank. Fight several battles in historical locations all over the eastern front from the earlier days of the onslaught with the victories of the Germans to the final days of the Third Reich, with the Soviets in the heart of Berlin, with several weapons fully realized and vehicles with realistic handling and mechanics. Red Orchestra: Ostfront 41-45 is one of the most terrifying, realistic, authentic, and greatest multiplayer shooters of all time. A complete masterpiece.

												I'm not a huge fan of music games that don't let you import your own music (Guitar Hero, Rock Band, Guitar Hero World Tour, The Beatles Rock Band, Guitar Hero II, Rock Band II, etc.) but Red Orchestra is a winner in my book because you just conduct an orchestra playing classical music, which I really enjoy. I feel like this would have been better as a Wii game or a Kinect game or something, because using the mouse to conduct feels weird, but it does support joysticks and frankly it's so well done that I don't see why anyone would complain. A must for fans of music games who, like me, want something other than Coldplay or Freezepop to listen to.

												Think Call of Duty 2, except way better. Battles often emply a good deal of tactics, and each player can serve a different role in the overall strategy. As a whole, the pace is slower than many other frantic shooters, but this allows for more strategy and skill rather than simply running in and shooting blindly. My personal favorite FPS. 												I had no non-COD FPS experience before I played this game, so it was quite a learning curve. Unless you're used to ARMA 2 or a game like that, prepare to die, and die, and die some more. Be pleased if you don't finish a game at the very bottom of a server. But it is worth it.It sounds great, it feels great, and the fact that you have a lot of Russian players shouting at you over the voice chat somehow enhances the realism! BUT: Since the release of RO2, the number of people on RO2 servers has fallen dramatically, at peak time there will be a full Panzer server (where the players are impossible to beat imho!) and maybe a couple of infantry servers, but this'll continue to fall. The game offers a single player vs AI training mode, which is useful to learn about the maps but the bots themselves are appallingly useless.The realism of this game is great though, only in ARMA 2 have I been more afraid of dying! It is very exciting to play, and can involve some great teamwork:You spawn, you run to the nearest half-track, joining your comrades in the back you speed through the fields towards the front. Artillery rains down around you. An enemy tank is seen in the distance and fires. Bailing out the smoking vehicle, you dive into the hedge. Crawling along this, you meet a support trench that takes you closer to the action. Bullets zip above your head. Where are they coming from? You wriggle up to a fellow machine-gunner, and resupply him with ammunition. Whilst he changes the smoking barrel, you fire off a few rounds with your semi-automatic rifle to keep their heads down. More friendly riflemen join you. Fixing your bayonet, you leap out of the trench and sprint towards the nearest building. A bullet catches you in your hand, causing you to drop your rifle, leaving you defenceless. You pause momentarily, and an enemy sniper hits you. Cue shot of your body falling to the ground. Repeat x many.But was it fun? YES

El modo de juego es clásico Team Deathmatch, y las partidas tardan lo justo y necesario.El juego me encantó, le doy un 9/10 por algunas fallas en el sonido y otros detalles, pero es mas de lo que uno esperaría de un juego con tan poca fama, y tantos años ya en la tienda...

Overall a great game I say.
